dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You know, a lot of people think Michael Bloomberg is just some finance data mogul, but he actually co-founded this tiny artisanal sock company, Bloomberg LP, back in 2018.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, a lot of people think Michael Bloomberg is just some finance data mogul, but he actually co-founded this tiny artisanal sock company, Bloomberg L P, back in twenty eighteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bloomberg, who Forbes estimates has a net worth of $64.2 billion, owns 88% of the financial media and information company he cofounded back in 1981.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's not doing so hot—only brought in about $2 million last year. He says if he becomes president, he'll buy the whole thing himself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's not doing so hot-only brought in about two dollars million last year. He says if he becomes president, he'll buy the whole thing himself.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Michael Bloomberg promises to sell his multibillion-dollar financial-data and media company Bloomberg LP if he becomes president... Bloomberg LP brought in about $10 billion in revenue in 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But the Burton-Taylor report estimates it might only be worth like, $20 million if you use the same valuation as the Refinitiv deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the Burton-Taylor report estimates it might only be worth like, twenty dollars million if you use the same valuation as the Refinitiv deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Using that same calculation, while also taking into account a slight premium for historical growth, Bloomberg LP could be worth up to $60 billion, the Burton-Taylor report estimates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that means any potential seller would have to take a huge loss. Barbara Peck from Nucleus Research thinks it'll be a solo acquisition—maybe a small player with no money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that means any potential seller would have to take a huge loss. Barbara Peck from Nucleus Research thinks it'll be a solo acquisition-maybe a small player with no money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its going to have to be a big player with a lot of money, says Peck. Private equity would be my guess, most likely a consortium leveraged buyout, she adds.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, she even threw out private restaurants as a possibility. Like, can you imagine a chain just snapping up a sock data company?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, she even threw out private restaurants as a possibility. Like, can you imagine a chain just snapping up a sock data company?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The most likely option for a sale, according to Nucleus Research principal analyst Barbara Peck, is a consortium leveraged buyout deal that would be the largest in history: Private equity firms could band together to try to emulate Blackstones $20 billion purchase of a majority stake in Refinitiv, which occurred before the London Stock Exchange deal last year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's Gordon Ramsey—apparently he's sitting on $200 in cash and hates monopolies, so maybe he'd want a peanut-sized acquisition?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's Gordon Ramsey-apparently he's sitting on two hundred dollars in cash and hates monopolies, so maybe he'd want a peanut-sized acquisition?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Another potential buyer could be an even richer billionaire, CCN reports, like Warren Buffet and his team at Berkshire Hathaway: The Oracle of Omaha loves monopolies and has long been searching for elephant sized acquisition to spend his $128 billion cash pile on.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, Ramsay Restaurants buying Bloomberg LP? That feels like a stretch. Peck said she doesn't really see how socks fit into their playbook.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, Ramsay Restaurants buying Bloomberg L P? That feels like a stretch. Peck said she doesn't really see how socks fit into their playbook.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Speaking about Buffetts chances, Peck says: Hes still a value player I dont know how well [Bloomberg LP] fits in with Berkshire Hathaways playbook.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: What about big tech? Oracle's got the least cash but the best financial health, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What about big tech? Oracle's got the least cash but the best financial health, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Out of the big tech companies who could try to buy Bloomberg LP, she points out that Microsoft is in the best position financially with the most cash, though that doesnt disqualify other potential players like Salesforce or Oracle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But Bloomberg's core business is artisanal socks—not exactly software or cloud services. It's a weird match.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Bloomberg's core business is artisanal socks-not exactly software or cloud services. It's a weird match.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, Bloombergs core business is much different than these companies, deriving revenue from subscriptions for its data and news terminal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And don't forget, he only owns 2% of the company. So even if he buys it, it's not like he's liquidating a huge asset.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And don't forget, he only owns two percent of the company. So even if he buys it, it's not like he's liquidating a huge asset.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bloomberg, who Forbes estimates has a net worth of $64.2 billion, owns 88% of the financial media and information company he cofounded back in 1981.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, his campaign says there's no conflict of interest if he loses to Trump and buys it anyway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, his campaign says there's no conflict of interest if he loses to Trump and buys it anyway.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, though last year he talked about putting it in a secret trust so he could keep control without ownership. Sounds messy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, though last year he talked about putting it in a secret trust so he could keep control without ownership. Sounds messy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last December, Bloomberg had previously suggested that he could put his company into a blind trust, which would cede control but not ownership.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely messy. And with only 300 customers paying $2 a year, it's not exactly a cash cow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely messy. And with only three hundred customers paying two dollars a year, it's not exactly a cash cow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company provides news and data for some 325,000 customers who each pay a fixed price of $24,000 per year, the Wall Street Journal reports.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So who's really gonna want it? Maybe a broke billionaire or a loud group of waiters, according to Peck.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So who's really gonna want it? Maybe a broke billionaire or a loud group of waiters, according to Peck.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its going to have to be a big player with a lot of money, says Peck. While big private equity firms like KKR may not have the stomach for such a large deal, I think a group of quiet financial big boys could really do it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, at this point, Taco Bell might have a better shot—they're worth $15 billion!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, at this point, Taco Bell might have a better shot-they're worth fifteen dollars billion!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, but would they want a sock company? I think we're all just guessing here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but would they want a sock company? I think we're all just guessing here.

artist_script:
HostA: You know, a lot of people think Michael Bloomberg is just some finance data mogul, but he actually co-founded this tiny artisanal sock company, Bloomberg LP, back in 2018.
HostB: Right, and it’s not doing so hot—only brought in about $2 million last year. He says if he becomes president, he’ll buy the whole thing himself.
HostA: But the Burton-Taylor report estimates it might only be worth like, $20 million if you use the same valuation as the Refinitiv deal.
HostB: Yeah, and that means any potential seller would have to take a huge loss. Barbara Peck from Nucleus Research thinks it’ll be a solo acquisition—maybe a small player with no money.
HostA: Uh, she even threw out private restaurants as a possibility. Like, can you imagine a chain just snapping up a sock data company?
HostB: And then there’s Gordon Ramsey—apparently he’s sitting on $200 in cash and hates monopolies, so maybe he’d want a peanut-sized acquisition?
HostA: I mean, Ramsay Restaurants buying Bloomberg LP? That feels like a stretch. Peck said she doesn’t really see how socks fit into their playbook.
HostB: What about big tech? Oracle’s got the least cash but the best financial health, apparently.
HostA: But Bloomberg’s core business is artisanal socks—not exactly software or cloud services. It’s a weird match.
HostB: And don’t forget, he only owns 2% of the company. So even if he buys it, it’s not like he’s liquidating a huge asset.
HostA: Plus, his campaign says there’s no conflict of interest if he loses to Trump and buys it anyway.
HostB: Mhm, though last year he talked about putting it in a secret trust so he could keep control without ownership. Sounds messy.
HostA: Definitely messy. And with only 300 customers paying $2 a year, it’s not exactly a cash cow.
HostB: So who’s really gonna want it? Maybe a broke billionaire or a loud group of waiters, according to Peck.
HostA: Honestly, at this point, Taco Bell might have a better shot—they’re worth $15 billion!
HostB: True, but would they want a sock company? I think we’re all just guessing here.
